Here's an email we have from Anthony in Mesa, Arizona.
I was in my first week of Marine boot camp as is the custom in that branch of boot camp, I saw a no television, heard no radio.
At age 18, I was left to grow up very fast by assessing the scope of my decisions.
I had to rely on my imagination to understand what happened that day.
I did not see video of that day and the patriotism there after until December of that year.
And let's see if we can get to Laura.
Laura is with us from Grand Rapids in Michigan.
Good afternoon.
Good afternoon.
I wanted to say that today is my third wedding anniversary.

And you know, in the process of planning of a wedding three years ago, we got a lot of interesting and mixed reactions from individuals who, you know, weren't so certain that we should be planning a wedding on a day as important as 9/11.
And you deliberately chose 9/11, though?
No.
We had chosen to get married on Saturday, September 10, but then it turned out that my parents had planned a vacation and weren't going to be able to attend.
If we chose that day and because of our honeymoon arrangement, we were kind of forced into choosing to do it the next day.
Which just happened to be Sunday, the 11th.
And so there you where.
And nevertheless, first of all, congratulations on your anniversary.
Thank you, thank you.
But it's got to come with - it's a strange association.

It does come with a bit of a strange association but, you know, my reaction to that is that, you know, it is a tremendously important day in American history and it should be remembered and the people that died should be honored.
You know, much in the same way that, you know, an event like Pearl Harbor is remembered and honored every year.
But, you know, it's also true that, you know, joyous things are going to happen, you know, on this date.
People are going to get married and people are going to have babies.

And, you know, just all kinds of events are going to occur on this date, and there's always going to be some juxtaposition between, you know, the tragedies that occurred and the happy things that happened for people.
The regular life that's happened on those 9/11 afterwards.
Laura, thanks very much.
And again, congratulations on your anniversary.
Thank you so much, bye-bye.
Here's this email we got from - I am trying to see - Melissa.
Melissa in the ninth grade from Clarkston, Michigan, 9/11 means a lot to us even if we barely remember it.
I was seven at that time and confused and scared during the entire day.

Instead of the image of thousands of Americans holding their heart as remembrance of 9/11, the plane crashes and the firefighters, I remember the tears of my second grade teacher, the huddles of older kids in the hallways, the whispers of terrorism.
For weeks afterwards, I had dreams about terrorists coming to my town before I realized that Clarkston, Michigan probably wasn't the number one target zone of al-Qaeda.
Every year since I have honored the day, as the day of confusion and sorrow in my childhood, however, this year, I was extremely frustrated with the lack of respect my high school showed.
There was no moment of silence, no announcement, definitely no assembly or anything honoring the terrible occasion, there is even a school dance tonight.
If anything, we don't honor 9/11 and those who died on that day nearly enough, at least not in the schools.
Thanks to all of you who wrote and who called on this seventh anniversary of 9/11.
